Posts.Content: malucho1 wrote: This AM (Saturday) I had a MRI of the cervical spine because I have had numbness in my fingers.These symptoms got me a referral to a neurologist, who is taking my symptoms very seriously. I have already done an EMG (?) to rule out carpal tunnel, which I don't have. In spite of the fact that I asked this neurologist a bunch of questions at my last appt, I still left without a clear sense of what this MRI might find. Except, of course, for the bone mets scenario. I still want to believe that bone/spinal cord mets is extremely unlikely. But waiting is a killer. I won't know until Jan 2 at the earliest because of all the holidays. Would really appreciate your good thoughts in the meantime. And any ideas of all the other diseases I can "hope" for: herniated disk, perhaps??? Dx 5/17/2006, IDC, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: MRI of cervical spine malucho1 TenderIsOurMight

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2007 04:32PM malucho1 wrote: Thanks for all the info, everyone. I really appreciate the support and collective knowledge. Corepat, I have been a vegetarian for 18 years. I will look into B-12 deficiency. I'll also ask about Tamoxifen. I have my regularly scheduled oncologist appointment on Friday. At my first appt. the neurologist did a very thorough exam and said he was 80% sure it was carpal tunnel. The next appointment he did the EMG and ruled out carpal tunnel. He said the next logical step would be to do the MRI. He didn't give me a list of things it could be or really what he expected. So here I am. Waiting. Breathe in. Breathe out. Trying to stay in the present moment. Cleaning the house for the New Year. Making resolutions. Writing affirmations. Lighting candles.
Posts.Title: MRI of cervical spine malucho1 TenderIsOurMight

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 08:06PM malucho1 wrote: "good" news! according to my onc. it is NOT mets. there is degeneration in the spine and I'll need to follow up with neurologist and spinal surgeon. I didn't get a copy of the report but I expect the neurologist will return my call early next week.Â  very very happy. onc says the chemo could have exacerbated the already existing spine issue. celebrated tonight with a blue moon beer and an early dinner at the vegan restaurant near the cancer center. woo-hoo. thanks to everyone for their support and smart thoughts!
Posts.Title: MRI of cervical spine malucho1 TenderIsOurMight

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2007 10:16PM - edited Dec 29, 2007 10:17PM by malucho1 I have the numbness on both hands. Mostly the fingers. BTW, I had a bilateral mastectomy with sentinel node biopsy on both sides. Could it be a result of the surgery??? I first noticed the numbness about 1 month AFTER the end of my chemotherapy treatments. The first time I felt it I was in a yoga class doing "triangle" pose. I couldn't feel my hand up in the air. It was a very strange sensation. I wiggled it around and the feeling came back. Now, the numbness is in both hands. It comes and goes but seems to me to be slowly progressing. I notice it often. I appreciate the feedback so far! Very good info re. CTS from Tender. I'll keep that in mind. And, Donna, do you have numbness only on your lumpectomy side? That would give good evidence suggesting it may be related to surgery! My "gut" feeling is that mine must somehow be aggravated by/caused by the surgery or chemotherapy as I had never experienced anything similar before. However, the neurologist says that the chemo-induced neuropathy would have presented first in the feet and then moved up. Mine didn't do that. Another possibility might be Tamoxifen. As far as I know, hand numbness is not a known side effect but the timing would be exact. I started Tamoxifen about 1 month after I finished chemo and right when the numbness and tingling started. One more thing: I really hate to admit this— because it sounds a bit scary—but I sometimes have numbness in my lips as well. Other than that, I'm fit as a fiddle. LOL.
